awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Identity Theft Remediation and the Production of Economic Insecurity
awd_abstract_narration:
Identity theft is often considered one of the fastest growing and most pressing financial crimes in the United States. Each year it affects millions of Americans and results in financial losses for businesses and consumers in the tens of billions of dollars. Many victims also report negative emotional and physical effects and face inaccurate credit reports, unanticipated debt, and rejection for financial accounts, loans, or insurance. While prior research links these latter consequences to the complicated steps for resolving identity theft, it fails to offer an explanation for why individuals struggle to "recover their identities." By exploring that process in depth, this project will assess the efficacy of contemporary processes for resolving identity theft and their consequences for American households.

This project investigates identity theft resolution from the perspective of victims and the organizations they navigate. Through in-depth interviews with victims, it explores how individuals go about resolving identity theft and details the financial and emotional toll that experience takes on them and their families. It also examines the perceived issues and challenges facing organizations and government agencies involved in the remediation process by interviewing staff and observing work in key organizational contexts. Together, these methods will elucidate how managing personal data contributes to economic and other forms of insecurity in American households, as well as how actors negotiate risk and trust to repair breakdowns in expert systems for identification-sociotechnical systems central to the generally smooth operation of countless economic and political processes in everyday life.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Tens of millions of Americans experience some form of identity theft each year, resulting in billions of dollars in direct losses to businesses and consumers along with numerous other forms of financial and nonfinancial hardship. Despite the magnitude of the issue, we know relatively little about (1) how victims make sense of and cope with their experiences or (2) how cases get resolved, and with what consequences.

To deepen our understanding of these issues, Brensinger conducted over 100 interviews with victims and professionals who encounter cases, spent over 300 hours observing events and shadowing work in industry and nonprofit settings, and analyzed thousands of pages of documentary evidence, including training materials, industry guides, and regulations.

The project produced a number of important contributions in two areas. The first pertains to the operation of information systems. Brensinger and Eyal drew on material from the study to develop a general theory of how organizations identify people that accounts for the increasingly impersonal data-mediated nature of individuals' relationships with organizations. Brensinger is also developing an account of the work involved in assessing the accuracy of personal data and repairing misidentification in consumer banking.

Secondly, the project elaborates on the social and economic consequences of information systems and their breakdown. It offers an in-depth look at how identity theft generates economic insecurity--a sense of being financially vulnerable due to unpredictable events--by breaching individuals trust in other people, organizations, and systems. That is, identity theft can leave victims feeling concerned about the stability of their financial lives because they no longer feel confident about how certain other people (even family and friends), organizations (like banks or debt collectors), or systems (such as the Internet) will treat them and their personal data. The project also draws attention to the burden of managing personal data in everyday life--from shredding sensitive information and taking steps to boost a credit score to using a virtual private network (VPN)--and its implications for inequality. In particular, while institutions often hold individuals responsible for this work, it depends on unequally-distributed resources and networks of social relations, both of which shape individual agency to manage data in unequal ways.

This project resulted in a number of specific outputs to various stakeholders and audiences. For scholars, project findings informed Brensinger's dissertation, two published articles, multiple manuscripts anticipated for publication in academic journals, and numerous conference, seminar, and workshop presentations. Brensinger also shared findings from the study with practitioners in the form of tailored reports, advice on internal materials and practices, multiple presentations to industry and nonprofit associations, and a white paper on data justice coauthored with an organizational partner. Lastly, Brensinger also shared findings from the study with policymakers by submitting comments to proposed rulemaking and meeting with regulators to provide expert feedback on issues related to identification.
